frame.name: Biological_area
frame.definition:
<def-root> This frame contains words that denote large ecological areas as well as smaller locations characterized by the type of life present--in other words, geography locations as defined by biota.
<ex>I've spent a long time in the <fex name="Descriptor">rugged</fex> <fex name="Locale"><t>prairies</t></fex> <fex name="Container_possessor">of northern Llorwyn</fex>.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Constituent_parts
FE.definition: <def-root><fen>Constituent_parts</fen> make up a <fen>Locale</fen>. <ex>This is the oldest <fex name="Cnst">oak</fex> <t>forest</t> in California.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Container_possessor
FE.definition:
<def-root><fen>Container_possessor</fen> is the location of which the <fen>Locale</fen> is a part.
<ex>Jon explored the <t>forests</t> <fex name="ContP">of California</fex>.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Formational_cause
FE.definition: <def-root><fen>Formational_cause</fen> brings about the features of the <fen>Locale</fen>. <ex>Jon explored the <fex name="FormC">sun-scorched</fex> <t>savanna</t>.</ex> This FE is also used for words that indicate no salient formation. <ex>Jon explored the <fex name="FormC">virgin</fex> <t>woodland</t>.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Locale
FE.definition: <def-root>This FE identifies a stable bounded area, and is typically the designation of the nouns of Locale-derived frames. <ex>There used to be a <fex name="Locale"><t>forest</t></fex> in that valley.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Name
FE.definition: <def-root>This FE indicates the <fen>Name</fen>s of <fen>Locale</fen>s. <ex>Jon explored the <t>forests</t> <fex name="Name">of California</fex>.</ex> <ex>Jon hiked around <fex name="Name">Muir</fex> <t>Woods</t>. </ex> </def-root>

FE.name: Relative_location
FE.definition:
<def-root><fen>Relative_location</fen> identifies a place in respect to which a <fen>Locale</fen> is located.
<ex>All the <t>swamps</t> <fex name="RelLoc">outside of Georgia</fex> are dry.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Descriptor
FE.definition:
<def-root>Any description, characteristic, or property of the <fen>Locale</fen> which is not covered by more specific FEs.
<ex>Apparently they found him at the bottom of a <fex name="des">really deep</fex> <t>bog</t>.</ex></def-root>

lexUnit.name: woodland.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: land covered with trees.

lexUnit.name: mudflat.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a stretch of muddy land left uncovered at low tide.

lexUnit.name: swamp.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: an area of waterlogged ground; a bog or marsh.

lexUnit.name: prairie.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a large open area of grassland.

lexUnit.name: desert.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a waterless, desolate area of land with little or no vegetation, typically covered with sand.

lexUnit.name: forest.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a large area covered chiefly with trees and undergrowth.

lexUnit.name: bog.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: an area of very soft wet muddy ground

lexUnit.name: wood.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a small forest.

lexUnit.name: jungle.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: an area of land with dense forest and tangled vegetation, typically in the tropics.

lexUnit.name: swampland.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: a piece of land which happens to be swampy

lexUnit.name: rainforest.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a luxuriant, dense forest found in tropical areas with consistently heavy rainfall.

lexUnit.name: plain.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a large area of flat land with few trees.

lexUnit.name: meadowland.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: grassland, often used for the cultivation of grass.

lexUnit.name: heathland.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: an area of open uncultivated land, typically on acid sandy soil and covered with heather, gorse, and coarse grasses

lexUnit.name: copse.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a small group of trees.

lexUnit.name: glade.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: an open space in a wood or forest.

lexUnit.name: tundra.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a vast, flat, treeless Arctic region of Europe, Asia, and North America in which the subsoil is permanently frozen.

lexUnit.name: taiga.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: swampy coniferous forest of high northern latitudes, especially that between the tundra and steppes of Siberia.

lexUnit.name: marsh.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: an area of low-lying land which is flooded in wet seasons or at high tide, and typically remains waterlogged at all times.

lexUnit.name: marshland.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: a piece of land that happens to be marshy

lexUnit.name: fen.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a low and marshy or frequently flooded area of land.

lexUnit.name: moor.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a tract of open uncultivated upland, typically covered with heather.

lexUnit.name: grassland.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: a large area covered primarily with grass

lexUnit.name: mead.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a meadow.

lexUnit.name: lea.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: an open area of grassy or arable land.

lexUnit.name: veld.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: open, uncultivated country or grassland in southern Africa.

lexUnit.name: wold.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a piece of high, open, uncultivated land or moor.

lexUnit.name: thicket.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a dense group of bushes or trees.

lexUnit.name: savanna.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a grassy plain in tropcial and subtropcial regions, with few trees

lexUnit.name: mire.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a stretch of swampy or boggy ground.

lexUnit.name: bush.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: (in Australia and Africa) wild or uncultivated country.

lexUnit.name: greenwood.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a wood or forest in leaf, especially as a refuge for outlaws.

lexUnit.name: spinney.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a small area of trees and bushes.

lexUnit.name: scrub.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: a natural area defined by its abundance of shrubbery.

lexUnit.name: oasis.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: a green and fertile area in a desert

lexUnit.name: shrubbery.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: an area filled with shrubs
